pageData.text: The Comparative Mammalian Organ investigation includes the guided dissections of a heart, kidney, brain, and eye. As the central pump of the cardiovascular system, the heart forces deoxygenated blood toward the lungs and oxygenated blood to the various organs and tissues. The kidneys regulate solute levels in the blood and other body fluids. The brain regulates the body’s responses to stimuli, changes in the body’s internal or external environment. The eye captures and focuses light, and converts this stimulus into <button class=glossary-text>nerve</button> impulses, which are received and interpreted by the brain.

pageData.text: Fossils have long been a source of fascination for young and old alike. These remains of bygone species provide a snapshot of what life was like on Earth millions of years ago, especially as paleontologists and artists recreate what these ancient creatures must have looked like in their heyday. But how do scientists determine the function of certain structures without a live specimen to study?

The founder of comparative anatomy, Georges Cuvier (1769-1832) championed the notion that an understanding of function and behavior could be derived from fossils by studying their structures1. For example, the shape of a fossil’s teeth gives clues as to its diet: sharp teeth suggest a meat-diet and flat teeth suggest a plant-diet. The study of dinosaur fossils specifically has led paleontologists to conclude that they are most closely related to modern-day birds. Fossil evidence such as bone shape, composition, and placement, and the presence of fossilized feathers and eggs, provide a clear evolutionary relationship between dinosaurs – the theropod subgroup in particular – and birds2. 1Benton, M. J. (2010, March 8). Studying Function and Behavior in the Fossil Record. NCBI. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2830450/ 2Benson, R. (2021, December 21). It’s official: birds are literally dinosaurs. Here’s how we know. BirdLife International. https://www.birdlife.org/news/2021/12/21/its-official-birds-are-literally-dinosaurs-heres-how-we-know/

pageData.text: The body contains several different organ systems, each with specific roles for maintaining life. Each organ system consists of a number of organs that operate collectively to carry out specific body functions. At every level of organization, whether at the cellular, tissue, organ, or organ-system level, each structure always reflects its function and vice versa. This concept is known as the . Simply put, the function of a structure is directed by its anatomy. In this investigation, you will dissect and examine four different organs to understand the structure and function of each, as well as how the anatomical features contribute to the physiology.

Organ systems themselves do not operate independently, but rather are coordinated for the organism to survive. Interdependence of the organ systems is necessary for : the dynamic equilibrium the body sustains when it is in good health.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Mammalian organ systems

pageData.text: Each organ plays an integral part in ; however, the organs do not work independently. For example, the brain is part of the , which coordinates activities of all the organ systems. The brain gathers information about the internal and external environment of the body and formulates a response.

The eye is part of the that serves as a specialized sensory receptor. It receives stimuli and converts these signals into impulses that travel to the brain. The brain receives , not images, from the eye. It is the brain that interprets these impulses, giving us the perception of visual images. It is the brain that actually “sees” the image.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: The visual projection pathway of visual stimuli traveling from the eyes to the visual cortex at the posterior end of the brain.
pageData.desc: Figure 2: The visual projection pathway of visual stimuli traveling from the eyes to the visual cortex at the posterior end of the brain.

pageData.text: Although it regulates the activities of other organ systems, the brain cannot function without oxygen and nutrients. It relies on the cardiovascular system to transport nutrients and carry away wastes. The heart is part of the cardiovascular system and is involved in transportation of materials, such as nutrients and oxygen, throughout the body. Therefore, the heart has an important role in maintaining the vitality of the brain. If the oxygen supply to the brain is interrupted for more than a few minutes, brain cells start to die.

<button class=glossary-text >Cardiac muscle</button> is an involuntary type of striated muscle tissue (Figure 3) that does not need direct involvement from the brain in order to contract. Certain cardiac muscle cells are self-excitable, meaning they can initiate their own contraction signal, and transmit that signal to the rest of the heart in a spontaneous and rhythmic fashion. A region called the sinoatrial (SA) node sets the pace for these contractions, serving as the heart’s pacemaker. Adjacent cardiac muscle cells are electrically coupled, so that signals spread swiftly between them and the <button class=glossary-text>myocardiaum</button> functions as a coordinated unit.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: A micrograph of cardiac muscle tissue showing cross-hatching pattern of striations in the muscle fibers.
pageData.desc: Figure 3: A micrograph of cardiac muscle tissue showing cross-hatching pattern of striations in the muscle fibers.

pageData.text: In spite of the self-excitable nature of , the brain still exerts control over heart function. However, regulation of the strength and timing of the heartbeat begins in the of the oblongata (located in the brain stem). This region receives signals from sensory receptors and the . The cardiac center of the brain sends appropriate stimulation via to the SA node and other structures within and near the heart.

Not only is the cardiovascular system influenced by the brain, the kidneys also affect the cardiovascular system by regulating blood pressure. The kidneys are the <button class=glossary-text>urine</button>-forming structures of the urinary system. They filter the blood, removing toxins, metabolic waste products, and excess ions; at the same time, the kidneys restore needed substances to the blood. These actions directly affect blood volume which, in turn, affects blood pressure. Although the kidneys are essential, they cannot function without blood to process and without pressure to drive the filtration process. Therefore, there is a complex interdependence between the kidneys and the cardiovascular system.

The kidneys are under the control of the brain and the heart. The kidneys regulate blood pressure by regulating blood volume through the movement of ions (including Na+, K+, Ca2+, Cl-) and water, all of which affect osmotic balance. within the kidney are under the control of , produced by the tiny pituitary gland at the base of the brain. ADH stimulates the collecting ducts to reabsorb water. This action reduces urine production and increases blood volume. The resulting increase in blood volume mediates blood pressure increases. The heart also has control over osmotic balance in the kidney by producing . ANP controls the kidney’s reabsorption of Na+. ANP is secreted by the (receiving chambers of the heart) when cardiac muscle cells are stretched by increased blood volume. ANP causes an increase in Na+ excretion, also causing water to be removed. The result is lowered blood volume and blood pressure. Blood pressure must be tightly controlled because a high pressure can damage small blood vessels, such as capillaries in the brain and arterioles in the of the eye.

A set of mammalian organs is provided for dissection so that you can observe the structure of each and begin to explore and consider the physiological links between organ systems, which operate to maintain . In order to carry out the dissections accurately and efficiently, it is necessary to know the fundamental terminology of anatomy.

pageData.question: Which of the following best illustrates homeostasis?

options.text: Organ systems work together for organism survival.
The muscles of the heart contract without direction from the brain.
The reproductive systems of males and females differ.
An injury to one organ system damages all other organ systems.
The structure of an organ is indicative of its function.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Interdependence of the organ systems is necessary for homeostasis.

pageData.question: Which of the following statements about the interdependence of the nervous, cardiovascular and urinary systems is true?

options.text: The cardiovascular system regulates blood pressure by influencing the urinary system.
The nervous system processes visual stimuli from the eyes by signaling the urinary system.
The urinary system reabsorbs water based on signals from the peripheral nervous system.
The cardiovascular system regulates heartbeat based on signals from the eye.
The nervous system collects sensory data that is processed by the cardiovascular system.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The cardiovascular system regulates blood pressure by influencing the urinary system’s ability to control the water and ion content of blood.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Organ systems themselves do not operate independently, but rather are coordinated for the organism to survive. Interdependence of the organ systems is necessary for homeostasis. For example, the brain is part of the central nervous system, which coordinates the activities of all the organ systems. The brain gathers information about the internal and external environment of the body and formulates a response. The eye is part of the peripheral nervous system that serves as a specialized sensory receptor. It receives stimuli and converts these signals into nerve impulses that travel to the brain. And although it regulates the activities of other organ systems, the brain cannot function without oxygen and nutrients. It relies on the cardiovascular system to transport nutrients and carry away waste. The cardiovascular system, then, is influenced by the brain, which regulates the strength and timing of the heartbeat. The urinary system is regulated by both the cardiovascular system (which relies on blood volume changes to regulate blood pressure) and the nervous system (which includes glands such as the pituitary that regulate water absorption by the kidneys).

pageData.text: Anatomists and health care providers use a very specific terminology that enables them to precisely communicate their work. Directional anatomical terms are used for describing the relative positions of different body structures or to provide instructions for incisions. Directional anatomical terms (Table 1, Figure 4) are used in this and most other dissection guides to describe the relative positions of body structures. Therefore, learning these terms is essential for the understanding and study of anatomy.

tableData.text: Toward the front of the body; synonymous with ventral
Toward the back of the body; synonymous with dorsal
Toward the back or spine; synonymous with posterior
Toward the belly or abdomen; synonymous with anterior
A significant distance below the surface
Divides the body into longitudinal left and right portions
Divides the body into equal left and right halves
Perpendicular to the long axis; produces cross-sections
Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

pageData.text: The cardiovascular system is composed of a network of vessels lined with endothelium, a type of epithelium (covering and lining tissue). The walls of blood vessels may include connective tissue and smooth muscle. The heart is an expanded region of the cardiovascular system, so it is not surprising to find that it is made up of tissues very similar to those found in blood vessels. The interior spaces are lined with , the endothelial tissue of the heart. Some components, such as the valves, contain connective tissue, and the heart is enclosed in an outer connective tissue layer called the . The walls of the heart are composed mainly of , an involuntary type of striated muscle tissue. The middle, muscular layer of the heart wall is termed the .

The mammalian four-chambered heart allows for two cardiovascular pathways: the <button class=glossary-text >pulmonary circulation</button> and the <button class=glossary-text >systemic circulation</button> (Figure 5). Together, these two pathways carry blood throughout the body while maintaining separation of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood. The pulmonary circulation carries deoxygenated blood away from the heart through the capillaries in the lungs, and then returns oxygenated blood to the heart. The systemic circulation is responsible for providing this oxygen-rich blood to the rest of the body and returning it to the heart so it can enter the pulmonary circulation. These two interdependent circulatory loops enable mammals to use oxygen efficiently.

pageData.altText: Figure 5: Diagram showing the parts of the pulmonary circulation and the systemic circulation of the heart
pageData.desc: Figure 5: Diagram showing the parts of the pulmonary circulation and the systemic circulation of the heart

pageData.subTitle: Heart Structure and Function
pageData.text: The mammalian heart (Figure 6) consists of four chambers: two (receiving chambers) and two (powerful pumping chambers). Blood enters the right and left atria and leaves the heart via the right and left ventricles. When the atria contract, they push blood a short distance into the ventricles. From the ventricles, the blood is forced into the arteries and out of the heart. The muscular walls of the ventricles are much thicker than those of the atria; thus, ventricular contraction creates high pressure to send blood a greater distance. The walls of the left ventricle are particularly thick due to its role in propelling the .

The is the main vessel conveying oxygenated blood from the heart into the rest of the systemic circulation (see ). The curved region of the aorta near its attachment to the heart is known as the aortic arch. The brachiocephalic trunk (also known as the brachiocephalic artery) is a major branch from the aortic arch that splits apart to form the right subclavian artery, supplying the right forelimb, and right common carotid artery, supplying the right side of the head and neck. The left common carotid artery branches from the aortic arch to supply the left side of the head and neck, and the left subclavian artery branches afterward to supply the left forelimb.

pageData.altText: Figure 6: Diagram showing the path of the blood as it moves through the heart
pageData.desc: Figure 6: Diagram showing the path of the blood as it moves through the heart

pageData.text: To understand pulmonary and more clearly, the path of the blood must be traced through the heart, as shown in . Deoxygenated blood returning to the heart from the rest of the body enters the right atrium via the and vena cavae. When the atrial muscle contracts, blood is pushed into the right . When the right ventricle contracts, blood is forced into the pulmonary trunk, which branches to form the right and left pulmonary arteries. These two arteries carry blood to the lungs. As the blood enters capillary beds in the lungs, carbon dioxide diffuses out of the blood and into air sacs, and oxygen diffuses from the air sacs into the blood. This oxygenated blood returns to the heart through the pulmonary veins. This constitutes the .

The pulmonary veins empty blood into the left atrium, which contracts at the same time as the right atrium. Blood from the left atrium is forced into the left ventricle. As the contract, blood in the left ventricle is forced into the . The aorta conveys blood to arteries that branch to transport the oxygen-rich blood through the body. Oxygen is delivered to the various tissues of the body, and deoxygenated blood is conveyed back toward the heart through veins that eventually lead back to the vena cavae. This pathway of blood constitutes the systemic circulation.

These two cardiovascular pathways carry blood simultaneously. The heart chambers contract rhythmically to ensure that blood continues on its proper course. This rhythmic contraction and relaxation of the heart muscle is called the . During this cycle, the atrial walls contract. This contraction forces blood into the relaxed ventricles. As the relax, the muscular walls of the ventricles contract. Both ventricles then relax, completing the cycle.

Blood moving from an atrium to a ventricle must flow through an . There are two atrioventricular valves: the (also known as the mitral valve) on the left side of the heart, and the on the right. These valves allow for one-way flow of blood. When the ventricle contracts, the valve prevents blood from being forced back into the atrium. The valves are flaps, or cusps, of connective tissue anchored by strong fibers. These fibers are known as , and prevent the valves from opening during ventricular contraction. The chordae tendinae are anchored by found in the walls of the ventricles.

When blood is forced from the , it passes through . One semilunar valve, called the , is located where the leaves the left ventricle; the other, called the , can be found where the pulmonary trunk leaves the right ventricle. Once the ventricles have relaxed, the semilunar valves keep blood from moving back into the ventricles.

Because the heart is a continuously working muscle, it needs a constant supply of nutrients and oxygen. However, oxygen in the blood does not have time to diffuse across the thick endothelial lining of the chambers. The heart, therefore, has its own series of blood vessels that provide nourishment. The branches from the aorta as it leaves the heart. It then branches into arteries that carry oxygenated blood to the capillary beds within the heart walls. return oxygen-poor blood from the walls of the heart to the . The cardiac veins return blood to the coronary sinus, which opens into the right atrium.
The terms listed in Table 2 are used in this dissection and are important parts of the mammalian heart.

pageData.question: Pulmonary and systemic circulation each rely on the flow of blood through the heart. Which of the following best describes the blood in the heart as it facilitates these two cardiovascular pathways?

options.text: The right chambers contain deoxygenated blood; the left chambers contain oxygenated blood.
The right chambers contain oxygenated blood; the left chambers contain deoxygenated blood.
The atria contain deoxygenated blood; the ventricles contain oxygenated blood.
The atria contain oxygenated blood; the ventricles contain deoxygenated blood.
All chambers contain deoxygenated blood during pulmonary circulation; all chambers contain oxygenated blood during systemic circulation.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The right atrium and ventricle contain deoxygenated blood received from the body during systemic circulation. The left atrium and ventricle contain oxygenated blood received from the lungs during pulmonary circulation.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the functional differences between pulmonary and systemic circulation?

options.text: Pulmonary circulation oxygenates blood; systemic circulation distributes oxygenated blood.
Pulmonary circulation deoxygenates blood; systemic circulation collects deoxygenated blood.
Pulmonary circulation nourishes the lungs; systemic circulation nourishes the heart.
Pulmonary circulation filters out waste from blood; systemic circulation adds waste to blood.
Pulmonary circulation pumps blood to the body; systemic circulation pumps blood in the heart.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Pulmonary circulation is the circulation of blood between the heart and the lungs that allows deoxygenated blood to become oxygenated. Systemic circulation is the circulation of blood between the heart and the rest of the body so oxygenated blood can be delivered to body tissues and deoxygenated blood can be returned to the heart.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Practice retracing the pathways of pulmonary and systemic circulation. For pulmonary circulation, start at the right atrium and trace the flow of blood back to the heart. For system circulation, start at the left atrium and trace the flow of blood to the upper or lower body and back to the heart.

pageData.text: The primary function of the urinary system is , the control of solutes, mostly ions, in the blood and other body fluids. The kidneys (Figure 7) are the principle organs of the urinary system of vertebrate animals. They are two bean-shaped organs that filter the blood, remove waste from it, and produce , which contains waste as well as other substances such as water. Urine leaves the kidneys through the . Both ureters empty into a single that drains through the and out of the body.

The external surface of the kidney is covered in a thin, transparent layer of connective tissue called the (see Mammalian Kidney dissection mat). to the renal capsule is the , and deep to the cortex is the . The kidney contains several cone-shaped . Each lobe contains a surrounded by renal cortex that projects between the pyramids in structures called .

Blood flows into each kidney through the (Figure 7) at an indentation called the . The renal artery splits into branches called the . These branch further into . The interlobar arteries pass through the renal columns, and branch again forming the that run between the cortex and . These feed into , from which blood enters a capillary network, the of the .

The nephron (Figure 7) is the functional unit of the kidney. Each kidney contains over a million nephrons. The nephrons are responsible for blood filtration and urine production. The nephron is made up of two structures: the glomerulus and a . The glomerulus is an aggregation of capillaries surrounded by the (Bowman’s capsule); together, the glomerulus and its capsule are called the . The role of the glomerular capsule is to filter out large molecules and cellular material present in the blood.

pageData.altText: Figure 7: Labeled diagrams showing the structures of the kidney and it’s fuctional unit, the nephron
pageData.desc: Figure 7: Labeled diagrams showing the structures of the kidney and it’s fuctional unit, the nephron

pageData.text: Blood leaves the through the . The diameter of the is larger than that of the efferent arteriole, creating pressure in the capillaries of the glomerulus. This pressure forces water, salts, glucose, urea, amino acids, and waste products out of the blood capillaries and into the . Large particles, such as large molecules, plasma proteins, blood cells, and platelets remain in the capillaries as they are too large to pass through the capillary walls; these pass out of the glomerulus via the efferent arteriole. The fluid remaining in the capsule, called , will eventually become .

The filtrate passes into the first segment of the , the . Specialized cells in the proximal convoluted tubule selectively reabsorb salts and nutrients from the filtrate and transfer them into the adjacent . The descending limb of the loop, carrying the filtrate, runs down into the region of the kidney. Interestingly, the blood in the surrounding capillaries flows in a direction opposite that of the filtrate in the tubule. The solute concentration in the capillaries and surrounding fluid is higher than in the filtrate, so there is a concentration gradient that causes water to flow out of the filtrate and into the blood within the peritubular capillaries. This gradually concentrates the filtrate. The cells lining the descending limb are permeable to water but not to urea or ions, preventing these substances from moving out of the descending limb and being re-absorbed into the blood as the concentration of the filtrate increases.

The descending limb makes a hairpin turn, reversing its orientation at the (loop of Henle) and becoming the ascending limb of the nephron loop, which re-enters the cortex. Cells in this limb are impermeable to water, preventing osmosis from diluting the filtrate, but they are permeable to ions. Some of these move out of the filtrate in response to the concentration gradient established by the low external solute concentration. Toward the upper region of the ascending limb, solutes are actively transported out of the filtrate. The filtrate moves from the ascending limb into the , where more water is recovered and the solute concentrations are further adjusted.

The filtrate passes from the distal convoluted tubule into the , which descends into the medulla. Since the medulla has a high solute concentration, more water is lost from the filtrate to the surrounding tissue via osmosis. Several collecting ducts converge at the apex of the , a region that is called the . The collects urine from the papilla. The , in turn, collects urine from several minor calyces and conveys it into the . From there, it passes out of the kidney and into the .
The blood in the peritubular capillaries and efferent arteriole flows into the and from there the . The interlobar veins converge at the , which exits the kidney at the hilus.

pageData.question: Which of the following is the primary function of the urinary system?

options.text: osmoregulation of body fluids
solid waste excretion
blood glucose maintenance
hormone production

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The primary function of the urinary system is to control the solute content of blood and other body fluids, also known as osmoregulation.

pageData.question: The kidneys receive blood from the heart via the renal arteries. From there, the arteries branch into a series of smaller arteries and eventually a network of capillaries. Which of the following best describes the significance of the highly vascular structure of the kidneys?

options.text: The kidneys’ primary function is to regulate solutes in the blood.
The kidneys’ primary function is to deliver nutrients to the bloodstream.
The kidneys’ primary function is to maintain blood hormone levels.
The kidneys’ primary function is to remove cellular debris from lymph vessels.
The kidneys’ primary function is to recycle to the digestive system.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The kidneys are highly vascular to allow them to control solute levels in the blood, which they do by filtering blood and removing from it water and waste.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The urinary system is made up of four major structures that work together in osmoregulation, or the control of solutes in the blood and other body fluids. The two kidneys, which receive blood through a complex network of arteries, filter blood to maintain healthy solute concentrations and remove waste molecules. The liquid waste, or urine, leaves each kidney via a ureter. The two ureters empty into a single urinary bladder that holds the urine until it exits the body through the urethra.

The liquid waste, or urine, leaves each kidney via a ureter. The two ureters empty into a single urinary bladder that holds the urine until it exits the body through the urethra.

pageData.text: Two major cell types account for most of the tissue in the nervous system: , which receive and transmit electrochemical signals called , and (also called glial cells or neuroglia), which provide support for the neurons. There are multiple types of neurons and glia. A typical neuron (Figure 8) has three major components: the , which houses the nucleus and most of the organelles; an , which conveys impulses away from the cell body; and the , which convey impulses toward the cell body.

pageData.altText: Figure 8: Labeled diagram of a neuron and its components
pageData.desc: Figure 8: Labeled diagram of a neuron and its components

pageData.text: The nervous system has two major divisions: the , consisting of the brain and spinal cord, and the , a network of and ganglia (clusters of neuronal cell bodies) located outside the CNS. The nervous system can also be described in terms of and . Gray matter is made up mainly of neuronal cell bodies and dendrites, with some axons, together with glia and tiny blood vessels called capillaries. In preserved but unstained specimens, this type of nervous tissue appears gray. White matter appears white because the axons of which it is composed are sheathed in a fatty substance called . This myelin sheath is produced by certain glia, and facilitates the rapid transmission of nerve impulses along the axons. Preserved, unstained myelinated axons have a shiny, white appearance. In the PNS, bundles of such axons are termed nerves, and in the CNS, they are known as .

pageData.subTitle: Brain Structures and Their Functions
pageData.text: The brain is the most complex organ of the mammalian body. It has three major regions: the , , and . In addition, there is a region that coincides with the hindbrain and midbrain, known as the .

pageData.subTitle: THE HINDBRAIN
pageData.text: The hindbrain (Figure 9) includes two parts of the brain stem, which links the brain and spinal cord; these are the , which is continuous with the spinal cord and regulates involuntary activities such as breathing, heartbeat, vomiting, coughing, and sneezing; and the bulb-shaped , an important relay center that helps regulate sleeping and breathing. The is also part of the hindbrain; cauliflower-like in appearance, it is of great importance in motor (movement) control. The , consists of , and the deeper, branching is known as the .

pageData.altText: Figure 9: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the medulla, pons, and cerebellum labeled.
pageData.desc: Figure 9: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the medulla, pons, and cerebellum labeled.

pageData.subTitle: THE MIDBRAIN
pageData.text: The <button class=glossary-text>midbrain</button> (Figure 10) is the third part of the brain stem, and serves to relay sensory and motor information between the spinal cord and the rest of the brain. The two <button class=glossary-text>superior colliculi</button> of the midbrain help control the movement of the eyes, head, and neck in response to a stimulus such as a sudden loud noise or flash of light.

pageData.altText: Figure 10: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the midbrain labeled.
pageData.desc: Figure 10: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the midbrain labeled.

pageData.subTitle: THE FOREBRAIN
pageData.text: The (Figure 11) consists of the , , , and .

pageData.altText: Figure 11: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the hypothalamus, thalamus, and pineal body labeled.
pageData.desc: Figure 11: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the hypothalamus, thalamus, and pineal body labeled.

pageData.text: The is of particular interest because it contains specialized hormone-secreting , and is thus considered part of the endocrine system as well as the nervous system. The hypothalamus is crucial for regulating key processes that maintain .

The is a very important “relay center” in the brain. All sensory information, with the exception of olfactory information, is relayed through the thalamus on its way to the . Motor information from the and the of the cerebrum (discussed below) passes through the thalamus to the . In addition, the thalamus helps to regulate sleep and consciousness.

The <button class=glossary-text>pineal body</button> is a tiny endocrine gland located just <button class=glossary-text>inferior</button> to the <button class=glossary-text>posterior</button> portion of the thalamus. It is sensitive to light, and secretes the hormone melatonin, which is important in the regulation of circadian rhythms (activities, such as sleeping and waking, that occur on an approximately 24-hour cycle), and the onset of sexual maturity.

The cerebrum is particularly prominent in mammals. Divided into right and left hemispheres by a groove called the , the cerebrum organizes incoming sensory information, initiates voluntary motor activities, and is responsible for learning, memory, and judgment. The cerebral cortex has a distinctive wrinkled appearance.

The cerebral cortex consists of <button class=glossary-text>gray matter</button>, and the wrinkles increase the surface area of the cortex. The crests of the wrinkles are called <button class=glossary-text>gyri</button> (singular, gyrus) and the shallow grooves are called sulci (singular, sulcus). <button class=glossary-text>White matter</button> <button class=glossary-text>tracts</button> lie deep to the gray matter of the cerebral cortex. The most prominent of these is the <button class=glossary-text>corpus callosum</button> that connects the cerebral hemispheres. Embedded in the white matter are collections of gray matter known as the basal nuclei (or, in some older texts, the basal ganglia). The basal nuclei play important roles in voluntary and habitual movements, and in learning.

The <button class=glossary-text>cerebral cortex</button> can be structurally and functionally divided into regions referred to as lobes (Figure 12). The <button class=glossary-text>frontal lobe</button> is responsible for cognitive processes such as planning, reasoning, judgement, and the control of emotional and sexual drives. The <button class=glossary-text>parietal lobe</button> integrates sensory information (for example, from receptors in the skin) and functions in spatial perception, i.e., the ability to assess the shape, size, orientation, and motion of objects. The <button class=glossary-text>temporal lobe</button> functions in auditory perception (including language) and long-term memory. The <button class=glossary-text>occipital lobe</button> receives and processes visual information.

pageData.altText: Figure 12: The human brain with the frontal, parietal, temporal and occipital lobes highlighted and labeled.
pageData.desc: Figure 12: The human brain with the frontal, parietal, temporal and occipital lobes highlighted and labeled.

pageData.text: The human brain contains four . The are located in the , separated by the . The is located between the two halves of the , and the is located between the and the brain stem.

pageData.subTitle: MENINGES
pageData.text: The is protected from injury in several ways. The bones of the cranium and spine provide support and resistance to impact. A series of three connective tissue layers called lie to these protective bones but external to the nervous tissue. The (also known simply as the dura) is the outermost of the meninges; the is a delicate layer that adheres closely to the surface of the CNS, and located between them is the , which has a texture similar to that of a spider web.

pageData.subTitle: VENTRICLES
pageData.text: The CNS is essentially a hollow tube, having internal spaces filled with clear, colorless . The brain contains four interconnected, CSF-filled ventricles. The right and left lateral ventricles are located in the cerebrum, separated by the septum pellucidum. The third ventricle is located between the right and left halves of the thalamus; it contains a specialized epithelium called the that produces the CSF. The fourth ventricle is located between the cerebellum and the brain stem.

CSF circulates through the central canal of the spinal cord and the four of the brain, and within the , which lies between the and the . CSF is a vital part of CNS circulation, and, especially within the subarachnoid space, helps to cushion the CNS and serve as a “shock absorber.”

pageData.subTitle: SENSORY STRUCTURES
pageData.text: Sensory structures related to vision and the sense of smell (olfaction) are prominently visible on the external, <button class=glossary-text>inferior</button> aspect of the brain.

The of the eyes are mainly composed of nervous tissue, and are considered part of the brain. Retinal give rise to the originating in each eye. The pair of optic nerves come together to form an X-shaped structure, the (or optic chiasma), located near the base of the brain near the . This is where many fibers decussate, or crisscross, before continuing via the to the . Decussation of nerve fibers carrying visual information is essential for binocular vision (i.e., the formation of a single, continuous image using input from both eyes).

The <button class='glossary-text'>olfactory bulbs</button> lie <button class=glossary-text>anterior</button> to the optic chiasm. They are quite prominent in mammals with a keen sense of smell, and even humans, with our relatively weak olfactory abilities, possess olfactory bulbs. Olfactory information is not relayed through the thalamus; rather, it passes to a number of brain areas, including those devoted to memory and emotion, as well as sensory perception.
The terms listed in Table 4 are used in this dissection and are important structures of the mammalian brain.

pageData.text: Note: All mammalian brains are similar in structure and function. However, there is one distinct difference between the brain stem and spinal cord of a biped, such as a human, and those of a quadruped, such as a sheep or cat (see Figure 4). A biped is a vertical animal that walks on two legs; thus, the spinal cord and brain stem are perpendicular to the ground. The spinal cord and brain stem of a quadruped are parallel to the ground.

pageData.question: While running for the ball, two athletes crash into one another. One athlete hits the back of their head on the ground and is taken to the sidelines. As they talk to the team doctor, they describe that upon hitting their head they saw bright flashes of light. Which of the following best explains the relationship between the athlete’s injury and the flashes they saw?

options.text: The back of the head is where the occipital lobe of the mammalian brain is located.
The back of the head is where the mammalian brain stem is located.
The back of the head is where the right hemisphere of the cerebrum is located.
The back of the head is where the temporal lobe of the mammalian brain is located.
The back of the head is where the cerebral cortex of the mammalian forebrain is located.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The occipital lobe, which receives and processes visual information, is located at the back (anterior side) of the mammalian brain. Hitting this part of their head caused the athlete to perceive flashes of light in their field of vision that weren’t there.

pageData.question: A young woman has just returned home after recovering from a brain injury. Despite a scar on her forehead, she is perfectly healthy; however, the woman’s friends and colleagues describe her as uncharacteristically irritable and rash after the accident. Which of the following best describes the nature of the woman’s injury?

options.text: The woman injured part of her frontal lobe.
The woman’s temporal lobes were removed as part of the surgery.
The woman’s corpus callosum was severed.
The woman injured her brain stem.
The woman’s injury caused more basal nuclei to develop in her brain.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The frontal lobe is responsible for cognitive processes, such as judgment, reasoning and control of emotional and sexual drives. It is likely that the personality changes described by her close associates were a result of damage to a portion of the woman’s frontal lobe.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The prominent cerebrum of the mammalian forebrain can be organized in several different ways. It can be viewed as right and left halves, or hemispheres, divided by a deep groove called the medial longitudinal fissure. These hemispheres are connected by a large tract of white matter called the corpus callosum. The cerebrum can also be viewed as different regions or lobes. The frontal lobe facilitates cognitive processes like reasoning and emotion. The parietal lobe processes sensory and spatial information. The temporal lobe facilitates language processing and long-term memory. The occipital lobe receives and processes visual information.

img.alt: Figure 12: The human brain with the frontal, parietal, temporal and occipital lobes highlighted and labeled.

pageData.text: The <button class=glossary-text>principle of complementarity of structure and function</button> becomes quite apparent when examining the mammalian eye. All specialized structures of the eye must work together with the nervous system in order for visual information to be perceived (Figure 13). In this investigation, a cow eye will be examined and dissected to delineate the relationship between structure (anatomy) and function (physiology).

pageData.altText: Figure 13: A diagram of light traveling from an object to the retina of an eye.
pageData.desc: Figure 13: A diagram of light traveling from an object to the retina of an eye.

pageData.text: Pathway of pupil reflex by Ruth Larson is available under Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unreported License at https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:Anatomy_and_physiology_of_animals_How_light_travels_from_the_object_to_the_retina_of_the_eye.jpg

pageData.subTitle: Eye Structure and Function
pageData.text: The eye is a key part of the visual apparatus that provides information about the size, shape, orientation, and location of objects in the environment. Light enters the eye through the transparent, window-like and passes through a small opening in the pigmented called the . Changes in the diameter of the pupil regulate the amount of light that enters the eye and passes through the biconcave . The , located immediately to the iris, is a muscular structure that is attached to the lens via . Contraction and relaxation of the ciliary body alter the shape of the lens, enabling near or distant focus. From the lens, light is projected onto the photosensitive at the back of the eye. Interestingly, the projected image is inverted relative to the objects being viewed. The retina contains that form the , which conveys signals to the brain. The brain processes the visual information so that images are perceived “right side up.”

pageData.altText: Figure 14: A longitudinal cross section of a human eye with the cornea, iris, pupil, lens, coronary body, suspensory ligament, retina, and optic nerve labeled.
pageData.desc: Figure 14: A longitudinal cross section of a human eye with the cornea, iris, pupil, lens, coronary body, suspensory ligament, retina, and optic nerve labeled.

pageData.text: There are two common ways of describing the overall anatomy of the eye. First, the eye can be divided into and compartments, separated by the lens. The anterior compartment is filled with a watery fluid called the , and the posterior with a gelatinous fluid called the (in the early days of Western medicine, body fluids were referred to as humors). Both fluids contribute to maintaining the spherical shape of the eye. The aqueous humor is constantly produced by the and circulates, providing lubrication for the , before being resorbed into the bloodstream. The vitreous humor is formed during development of the eye and is not replenished. The is an indentation in the anterior portion of the vitreous humor that helps hold the lens in place. Posteriorly, the vitreous humor serves to hold the in place.

pageData.altText: Figure 15: A longitudinal cross section of a human eye with the anterior and posterior compartments labeled.
pageData.desc: Figure 15: A longitudinal cross section of a human eye with the anterior and posterior compartments labeled.

pageData.text: The eye can also be divided into three concentric layers, known as tunics; the outermost , the middle , and the innermost . The is the most anterior region of the fibrous tunic; the tough, opaque forms the posterior part of the fibrous tunic, which protects the eye and helps maintain the shape of the eyeball. The vascular tunic, named for its role in supplying blood to the eye, consists of the iris, ciliary body, and . A high concentration of dark pigment in the choroid reduces the scattering of light rays in the eye. The choroid of many animals, including cows, cats, and dogs (but not humans), has a reflective region known as the , which enhances night vision. The nervous tunic consists of the retina and contains the photoreceptor cells.

The retina is actually a multilayered array of . The anterior layer—the first layer of neurons encountered by incoming rays of light—consists of ganglion cells, the of which converge at the to form the . Because there are no photoreceptors at the optic disc, it is often called the “.” Next, the light passes through additional layers of neurons, including the bipolar cells, which assist in the processing and transmission of visual information. Finally, the light strikes the photoreceptors, the rods and cones of the retina. Rods are sensitive to low levels of light, but are not sensitive to color. Cones function best in bright light. Because different types of cones are responsive to different wavelengths of light, cones enable color vision. The is the anterior boundary of the photoreceptor-containing portion of the retina. From the ora serrata, the retina extends anteriorly to the ciliary body.
The terms in Table 5 are used in this dissection of the mammalian eye.

tableData.text: Clear, watery fluid that fills the anterior chamber of the eye
Pigmented layer between the retina and sclera that absorbs scattered light; part of the vascular tunic of the eye
Muscular structure located posterior to the iris; attached to the lens via suspensory ligaments; part of the vascular tunic
Transparent anterior portion of the fibrous tunic of the eye
Outermost layer of the eye, consisting of the anterior cornea and posterior sclera
Indentation in the anterior portion of the vitreous humor that helps hold the lens in place
Pigmented diaphragm that alters pupil diameter to control the amount of light entering the eye
Biconvex, transparent structure that focuses light onto the retina
Innermost layer of the eye, or retina
The region of the retina where the optic nerve arises; contains no photoreceptors, and thus is commonly known as the “blind spot”
Links the retina of the eye to the brain; also called cranial nerve II
Anterior boundary of the photoreceptor-containing portion of the retina; has a serrated appearance in many vertebrate species
Opening in the center of the iris that changes diameter to regulate the amount of light entering the eye
Nervous tunic of the eye; contains rod and cone photoreceptors, plus additional types of neurons that process and transmit visual input
Posterior part of the fibrous coat of the eye; covers most of the outer surface of the eye; commonly known as the “white of the eye”

Fibers that join the ciliary body to the lens, thereby holding the lens in place and allowing contraction and relaxation of the ciliary body to adjust the shape of the lens; also called the zonula ciliaris
Reflective region of the choroid present in some vertebrates; enhances vision in low-light conditions
The middle layer of the eye, consisting of the choroid, iris, and ciliary body
Clear, gelatinous substance that fills the posterior compartment of the eye; also called the vitreous body

pageData.question: As part of your dissection of a cow eye, you will cut the eye into anterior and posterior halves using a scalpel and dissection scissors. As you do so, you will cut through the tunic layers of the eye. Which of the following describes the tunic layers in order from outermost to innermost?

options.text: fibrous tunic, vascular tunic, nervous tunic
fibrous tunic, nervous tunic, sclera
nervous tunic, fibrous tunic, vascular tunic
sclera, choroid, tapetum lucidum
vascular tunic, nervous tunic, fibrous tunic

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The fibrous tunic is the outermost layer of the eye; the vascular tunic is the next layer down and the nervous tunic is the innermost layer.

pageData.question: Which of the following best describes the innermost tunic of the mammalian eye and its function?

options.text: nervous tunic; receives visual stimuli
fibrous tunic; protects internal structures
vascular tunic; increases scattering of light
vascular tunic; supplies blood
nervous tunic; relays signals to brain

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The innermost tunic of the eye is the nervous tunic, which contains photoreceptor cells that perceive visual stimuli.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Not only is the shape of the eye maintained by the fluids it contains, but also by the concentric tissue layers that surround it, known as tunics. The outermost fibrous tunic features the cornea at its most anterior region and the tough, opaque sclera at its posterior. The middle vascular tunic is named for its vascular network that supplies blood to the eye. The innermost nervous tunic contains the photoreceptor cells that allow the eye to perceive visual stimuli.

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. To prepare, set up the work area and dissection tools. In Activity 1, locate and identify external structures of a heart. Then, divide it along the frontal plane, and locate and identify its internal structures. In Activity 2, locate and identify external structures of a kidney. Next, divide it in half longitudinally, and locate and identify its internal structures. Then, open and examine the ureter. In Activity 3, locate and identify external structures of a brain. Next, divide it in half longitudinally, and locate and identify its internal structures. Then, create a cross section of the frontal lobe, and identify the cerebral gray and white matter. In Activity 4, remove excess superficial fatty tissue from an eye, and locate and identify the eye’s external structures. Next, divide it into anterior and posterior halves. Then, locate and identify the structures of the anterior and posterior halves.

pageData.text: Follow the instructions for this activity closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE); safety glasses or goggles, gloves, and lab aprons must be worn when dissecting. Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing the dissection. Use proper hygiene practices before, during, and after the lab, including washing your hands before and after performing the dissection. Review pertinent portions of any Safety Data Sheets (SDS) before beginning the activity. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.
Isopropyl alcohol (rubbing alcohol) is flammable. Keep away from open flame if using alcohol as disinfectant.
pageData.altText: flammable symbol

pageData.text: Dissections require special attention to safety. Please follow these additional precautions:

text: Clean the counter or workspace thoroughly before and after the dissection, using isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant).
Wash your hands thoroughly with soap and water before and after the dissection.
Only perform the dissection on the dissection tray. This will contain both the specimen and any excess fluids.
Spread the absorbent pad blue side down underneath the tray to capture any spilled fluid.

In general, scissors are used more frequently than the scalpel, especially when care must be taken not to cut too deeply into the specimen. View the <button class='resource-text'>Cutting a Specimen</button> video.
Scalpels are used infrequently in most dissection labs and require special handling and disposal. View the <button class='resource-text'>Using a Scalpel</button> video.

pageData.text:
• Never cut toward your holding hand and fingers.
    • Cut in a downward motion using a steady, even pressure.
    • Always use a sharp blade.
    • Do not use a scalpel that is nicked, bent, or damaged.
    • Do not use a scalpel to cut through bone or heavy cartilage.
    • Never use a scalpel for anything other than dissection.

pageData.subTitle: Carolina’s Perfect Solution®
pageData.text: Independent, certified laboratory analyses of specimens fixed in Carolina’s Perfect Solution® have found that it is nontoxic and does not give off dangerous fumes. This means that, for safety purposes, use of Carolina’s Perfect Solution® specimens does not require specialized ventilation. Carolina does recommend performing the dissection in a well-ventilated room with some active ventilation when working with any preserved specimens. For a home setting, this may include opening windows and turning on a ceiling fan. The safe nature of Carolina’s Perfect Solution® also means that in most localities there are no mandated disposal requirements.
Carolina’s Perfect Solution® causes mild skin irritation if suitable PPE is not worn. Avoid contact with skin and eyes. Do not ingest specimen, especially if you are or may become pregnant.
pageData.altText: warning symbol

pageData.subTitle: Storage of Specimens
pageData.text: If it is necessary to store the specimen between work periods, you may choose to place it in the plastic storage bag with as much of the original solution as possible. Establishing an airtight seal is the best way to retain specimen integrity and prevent drying out of the specimen. First, squeeze as much air out of the specimen bag as possible before securing the opening with a rubber band, tape, or a binder clip. After closing the bag, the specimen can be stored in a larger, airtight box or bag at room temperature.

pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

It is the relationship between an anatomical structure and its function.

It occurs during the conversion of filtrate to urine.
It is the movement of the body.

posterior

caudal

assestmentData.question: Which of the following is a best practice when using a scalpel?

options.text: Never cut toward your holding hand and fingers.
Cut in an upward motion.
It is acceptable to use a scalpel that is nicked or bent.
Only use a scalpel to cut through bone or heavy cartilage.
You can use a regular kitchen knife instead of a scalpel.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following safety hazards is associated with isopropyl alcohol, which you will use for workstation disinfection?

options.text: It is flammable.
It is a corrosive material.

assestmentData.question: How should you store your specimen if you cannot complete the full dissection in one session?

options.text: The specimen is placed in its storage bag with as little air as possible.
The specimen is placed on the foam tray in the refrigerator.
The specimen is placed in a jar with as much of the original solution as possible.

The specimen is placed in an opaque container.

assestmentData.question: Gray matter and white matter in the brain differ in their structure and function. Which of the following best describes these differences?

options.text: White matter has myelinated neurons and rapidly transmits nerve impulses.
Gray matter has enlarged cell bodies and supports the brain with nutrients.
White matter is made up of glia and secretes hormones.
Gray matter is made of epithelial tissue and produces cerebrospinal fluid.
Gray matter is only found in the brain stem and facilitates involuntary processes.

The heart is the center of the cardiovascular system. It pumps oxygenated blood throughout the body, and deoxygenated blood to the capillaries of the lungs. In this activity, you will be guided through the dissection and close examination of an adult mammalian heart.

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Identify external and internal anatomical features of the heart.
Apply anatomical terminology while performing a heart dissection.
Describe the functions of the chambers, valves, and major vessels of the heart.
Distinguish between the pulmonary and .
Trace the flow of blood through the heart.

pageData.text: Review the dissection instructions and the glossary at the end of this activity.
Print out the dissection procedure to avoid getting fluid from the specimen on your computer or mobile device.
Clean the work area. Put on your PPE: safety goggles, gloves, and lab apron, and keep them on during the dissection and cleanup.
Lay the pad on the work area with the white, absorbent side facing up.
Lay the scalpel, forceps, probe, and hand lens (if available) on the pad. You may wish to use the T-pins to indicate structures for photos.
Inspect the scalpel. Do not use the scalpel if it is bent, nicked, or damaged.
Place the dissecting tray in the middle of the pad to absorb any fluid that might spill onto the work area.
Position the dissection mat so it is easily viewed.

The most important step in the heart dissection is placing the heart in the correct anatomical position. When the heart is in the anatomical position, it will be () side up (facing you), and () side down (against the absorbent pad). The left side of the heart will be on your right, and the right side of the heart will be on your left. Use the dissection mat for reference.

Note: In many drawings and photographs of correctly-positioned mammalian hearts, you will notice that the apex points to the left (your right). The apex may not be as easy to locate on your specimen, because the preservation and packing processes often cause distortion. You can find the anterior side by looking for the T-shaped pulmonary trunk extending up and branching into the pulmonary arteries. You can confirm that you are looking at the anterior side of the heart by locating the atrial appendages. They will be oriented anteriorly, much like forward- pointing dog’s ears.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Locate and identify as many externally-visible structures as possible, using the dissection mat as a guide. Numbers in parentheses correspond to numbered structures on the heart dissection mat. In the following steps you are asked to identify and photograph a number of structures. Each photograph may have multiple structures pinned or presented. Take notes to keep track of which structures are presented in each picture.

text: Use the forceps to grasp the tough, <button class=glossary-text>superficial</button> epicardial layer that adheres tightly to the heart.
Approximate the locations of the right (20) and left (12) and right (21) and left (15) , using the coronary sulcus (8) and interventricular sulcus (11) as guides.
Note the atrial appendages (4) and the heart apex (3).

Gently insert the blunt end of the probe into each of the following vessels: pulmonary artery (17) and pulmonary trunk (18), pulmonary vein, vena cava (22), vena cava (9), and (1). It is suggested that you then insert a single pipe cleaner or straw into each vessel, noting the color corresponding to each, and then take a photo.

pageData.text: Caution: Do not reuse pipe cleaners or straws that have come into contact with preserved tissue. Discard them in household trash after use.
Now you will open the heart along its <button class=glossary-text>frontal plane</button> in preparation for examining its internal structures.

text: Position the heart for a longitudinal cut as shown on the front of the dissection mat. You will be looking down on the left atrium, and the apex will be pointing toward you.
Using the scalpel, start your incision just below the left atrium. Make a incision, cutting all the way to the interventricular septum (10).
Continue the incision, slicing through the left ventricle until you have reached the apex.
Cut through the left atrium until you have reached the start of the original incision.

To complete the section, turn the heart over and cut from the apex through the right ventricle and right atrium. Now the heart should be cut completely in two along the frontal plane as shown on the back of the dissection mat.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Identify the internal structures of the heart, using the dissection mat as a reference. Take notes of which structures appear in each photograph so that you may label them later.

text: Locate both atria, both ventricles, and all large blood vessels (previously identified in step 2d above). Photograph them again to show what they look like from the interior of the heart. As you examine the inner ventricular walls, notice the trabeculae carneae (23). Note the very thin, transparent layer of lining the heart chambers.
Identify the aortic valve (2). Also locate the , which is not labeled on the mat, but lies between the right ventricle and the base of the pulmonary trunk.

Identify the biscupid (5) and tricuspid (24) valves, as well as the (7) and (16) attached to them. Inspect the valves and chordae tendinae, using a the hand lens if available, and compare their surfaces to those of the trabeculae carneae and the sectioned walls of the heart chambers. The trabeculae carneae, chamber walls, and papillary muscles are composed of tissue, whereas the valves and chordae tendinae are made up of connective tissue and endocardium.
Dispose of any excess fluids down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run for about 30 seconds to dilute the fluids.
Place the specimen in its storage bag and seal tightly. If you are finished working with your specimen, put the bag into an opaque trash bag for disposal in the household garbage.
Rinse and carefully air dry the dissection tools, and return the materials to your dissection kit.

Sanitize the workspace with isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant) and paper towels. If this is insufficient for removing grease during cleanup, use soap and water, followed by more alcohol/disinfectant.

pageData.text: The kidneys are the principal organs of the urinary system, and their primary function is the control of solute levels in the blood and other body fluids. In this activity, you will explore the anatomy of the kidney. Additionally, you will trace the path of blood as it flows through the kidney.

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Dissect a mammalian kidney.
Be able to identify major anatomical structures of the kidney.
Describe the path of blood flow through the kidney.
Discuss the relationship between kidney structure and function.

pageData.text: Review the dissection instructions and the glossary at the end of this activity.
Print out the dissection procedure to avoid getting fluid from the specimen on your computer or mobile device.
Clean the work area. Put on your PPE: safety goggles, gloves, and lab apron, and keep them on during the dissection and cleanup.
Lay the pad on the work area with the white, absorbent side facing up.
Lay the scalpel, forceps, probe, and hand lens (if available) on the pad. You may wish to use the T-pins to indicate structures for photos.
Inspect the scalpel. Do not use the scalpel if it is bent, nicked, or damaged.
Place the dissecting tray in the middle of the pad to absorb any fluid that might spill onto the work area.
Position the dissection mat so it is easily viewed.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Begin by observing the external features of the kidney, as shown on the left side of the front of the dissection mat. (Numbers in parentheses correspond to structures on the dissection mat.) In the following steps you are asked to identify and photograph a number of structures. Each photograph may have multiple structures displayed. Take notes to keep track of which structures are presented in each picture.

text: Observe the <button class=glossary-text>renal capsule</button> (11), the thin but tough transparent membrane that adheres closely to the surface of the kidney. Remove any adipose (fatty) tissue that may be attached to the capsule.
Locate the hilus (4). This is an indentation where the <button class=glossary-text>ureter</button> and blood vessels enter and exit the kidney.

Carefully remove excess adipose tissue to observe the ureter (21) more closely. Excess fat may be removed by pulling on the tissue gently with a pair of forceps. Fat should detach easily; use scissors only if necessary. The (10) and (20) may be difficult to locate as they were severed close to the hilus when the kidney was removed from the animal.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Using your scalpel, make a lateral, longitudinal cut through the kidney as shown on the right side of the front of the dissection mat. Locate the (13) and renal (15). The lies to the renal cortex. If you have a hand lens, use it to closely observe the appearance of each region.

The renal medulla consists of numerous conical structures called (18). The base of each pyramid lies next to the renal cortex, while the tip forms a (16). Each papilla projects into the renal sinus (19).

Renal pyramids are separated by bands of tissue called (12). Each column begins in the renal cortex and extends through the renal medulla. Examine the texture of this tissue. Columns have a granular texture similar to that of the renal cortex.

Each renal pyramid and adjacent cortical region defines a renal lobe (14). production takes place in the . Each renal papilla discharges urine into a cup-shaped (8). Four or five minor calyces merge to form a (7).

Major calyces merge to form the (17), with its wall of thick, fibrous tissue. Using a probe, trace the path of urine from the renal pyramids to the renal pelvis. Notice that the renal pelvis forms the expanded end of the ureter (21).

Using a scalpel, carefully cut one wall of the ureter and extend the incision to the hilus. Using a hand lens (if available), observe the fine ridges on the endothelial lining of the ureter and renal pelvis.

text: Dispose of any excess fluids down the drain with the water running. Allow the faucet to run for about 30 seconds to dilute the fluids.
Place the specimen in its storage bag and seal tightly. If you are finished working with your specimen, put the bag into an opaque trash bag for disposal in the household garbage.
Rinse and carefully air dry the dissection tools, and return the materials to your dissection kit.

Sanitize the workspace with isopropyl alcohol (or other non-bleach disinfectant) and paper towels. If this is insufficient for removing grease during cleanup, use soap and water, followed by more alcohol/disinfectant.

pageData.text: The mammalian brain is a highly complex organ that occupies the cranial cavity and plays a central role in regulating the body’s response to change in the internal and external environment. Whereas there are some differences in the size of the structures and regions of brains from different mammalian species,the general structures and their relative locations are the same or very similar in a human brain. In this investigation, the student will dissect and closely examine an adult sheep brain, and relate the structures observed to their functions.

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Identify the major regions of the brain and associate them with their basic functions.
Identify surface features of each region of the brain.
Apply anatomical terminology while performing a midsagittal dissection of an adult mammalian brain.
Identify the major internal features of the , diencephalon, , brainstem, and .

pageData.text: The mammalian eye is a complex and highly specialized sensory organ. The eye captures and focuses light, converting this stimulus into <button class=glossary-text>nerve</button> impulses which are eventually interpreted as an image by the brain. In this activity, you will be guided through the dissection and close examination of an adult mammalian eye.

pageData.title: Outcomes
text: Describe and identify the external and internal components of the mammalian eye.
Relate the structures of the eye to their functions.

pageData.text: Review the dissection instructions and the glossary at the end of this activity.
Print out the dissection procedure to avoid getting fluid from the specimen on your computer or mobile device.
Clean the work area. Put on your PPE: safety goggles, gloves, and lab apron, and keep them on during the dissection and cleanup.
Lay the pad on the work area with the white, absorbent side facing up.
Lay the scalpel, scissors, forceps, and probe from the dissecting set on the pad. You may wish to use the T-pins to indicate structures for photos.
Inspect the scalpel. Do not use the scalpel if it is bent, nicked, or damaged.
Place the dissecting tray in the middle of the pad to absorb any fluid that might spill onto the work area.
Position the dissection mat so it is easily viewed.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Use scissors and forceps to carefully remove excess <button class=glossary-text>superficial</button> fatty tissue from the outside of the eye. Use the photos from the upper left-hand area of the front of the dissection mat for reference. The photo on the left indicates an eye that is still covered in fatty tissue, and the photo on the right shows an eye with the fatty tissue removed.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Using the dissection mat as a guide, locate the optic (9), the opaque (13), and the transparent (5). You may wish to photograph these structures before proceeding. In the following steps you are asked to identify and photograph a number of structures. Each photograph may have multiple structures displayed. Take notes to keep track of which structures are presented in each picture.

Carefully slice the fibrous outer tunic of the eye in half along its - axis, as shown on the front upper right area of the dissection mat. Do not cut deeply into the eye or squeeze it too tightly, so as not to damage the interior structures. You may begin the cut with a scalpel and finish with small scissors, or you may use a scalpel for the entire cut. The watery fluid that comes out as you make the incision is the (1). If some of the (15) begins to come out of the eye as you cut through the sclera, let it come out slowly. As you cut, notice how tough the protective sclera is.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Examine the anterior half of the eye; locate and identify the lens (8). Gently remove the lens and squeeze it between your fingers. Notice that, unlike a camera lens, the lens of the eye is relatively soft.

Note: If you wish, pat the lens dry on the absorbent pad, then allow the lens to dry more overnight. Place it over a piece of paper with text printed on it, such as a newspaper. You should be able to observe the magnifying ability of the lens.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Orient the anterior half of the eye so that the cut portion is in contact with the tray and the cornea is facing up. Gently cut out the cornea at the point where it meets the sclera, as shown on the back of the dissection mat. Compare the transparent cornea to the opaque sclera that surrounds it. Cut the cornea in half to observe its thickness, then set it aside.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: The darkly-pigmented ring that is revealed when the cornea is removed is the (7). Just posterior to the iris is the (4), which connects the iris with the serrated tissue disk known as the (10).

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Use forceps to gently remove the iris and ora serrata as indicated on the back of the dissection mat, and examine these structures closely before setting them aside. If the vitreous humor remains in the eye, gently slip it out and set it aside as well. Try to locate the (6), the indentation in the central anterior region of the vitreous humor. Surrounding the hyaloid fossa are the (14) that suspend the lens and stretch it to focus. You may also notice dark lines around the hyaloid fossa. These lines contain pigment from the iris.

pageData.altText: camera symbol
pageData.text: Examine the posterior half of the eye. Identify the (12), which contains the photoreceptor cells. Locate the , or “” (2), which is the beginning of the . Notice the darkly pigmented choroid (3). The shiny, iridescent portion of the choroid is the .
