tableData.text: Toward the front of the body; synonymous with ventral
Toward the back of the body; synonymous with dorsal
Toward the back or spine; synonymous with posterior
Toward the belly or abdomen; synonymous with anterior
A significant distance below the surface
Divides the body into longitudinal left and right portions
Divides the body into equal left and right halves
Perpendicular to the long axis; produces cross-sections
Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

pageData.altText: Figure 4: Illustration showing where the midsagittal, frontal, and transverse planes divide a quadruped (cat) and a biped (human)
Figure 5: Diagram showing the parts of the pulmonary circulation and the systemic circulation of the heart
Figure 6: Diagram showing the path of the blood as it moves through the heart
pageData.content: Figure 6. Blood flow through the heart

tableData.text: Large artery that emerges from the left ventricle; carries blood to the systemic circulation
Pointed, lower end of the heart consisting of muscle from the left ventricle
Blood vessel that carries blood away from the heart
One of the two upper chambers of the heart that receive blood; the plural form is atria
Ear-like flap made up of muscle from the atrium; also termed an auricular appendage or auricle
Point of attachment for blood vessels entering and exiting the heart
Heart valve between the left atrium and ventricle; also called the left atrioventricular (AV) valve or mitral valve
Fibrous cords that connect atrioventricular valves with papillary muscles; also referred to as the “heart strings”
Artery leading from the aorta that supplies blood to the heart muscle
Groove that passes around the heart and separates the ventricles below from the atria above and is also known as the atrioventricular groove; runs perpendicular to the interventricular groove
Large vein that returns blood from the lower body regions to the right atrium
Muscular wall between the right and left atria
Groove that runs perpendicular to the coronary sulcus and indicates the position of the interventricular septum
Muscular wall between the right and left ventricles
Muscles anchoring the chordae tendineae to the atrioventricular valves
Pathway of blood that flows through the lungs and then returns the oxygen-rich blood to the heart
Valve between the aorta and left ventricle, and between the pulmonary trunk and right ventricle; often called the aortic valve and pulmonary valve, respectively
Large vein that returns blood from the anterior regions of the body to the right atrium
The pathway of blood to arteries that branch to transport the oxygen-rich blood through the body and veins that convey deoxygenated blood back to the heart
Ridges and folds on the walls of the ventricles
Heart valve between the right atrium and right ventricle; also called the right atrioventricular (AV) valve
Blood vessel that returns blood to the heart
One of the two lower chambers of the heart that force blood into either the aorta or the right and left pulmonary arteries, formed by branching of the pulmonary trunk

pageData.altText: Figure 7: Labeled diagrams showing the structures of the kidney and it’s fuctional unit, the nephron

tableData.text: Arteriole supplying blood to the glomerulus
Artery located between the renal cortex and renal medulla
Vein located between the renal cortex and renal medulla
Blood vessel that carries blood away from the heart
Cup-like division found in the renal medulla; minor calyces (plural) empty into major calyces
Duct that conveys urine from nephrons to a ureter; contributes to final reabsorption and secretion
Arteriole draining blood from the glomerulus
Depression where the renal artery, renal vein, and ureter enter and exit the kidney
Small artery supplying a renal lobe
Small vein draining a renal lobe
Network of capillaries associated with the nephron, involved in resabsorption and secretion of substances in filtrate
Branch from the abdominal aorta that supplies the kidney with oxygenated blood
Dense, irregular connective tissue layer that protects the kidney and helps maintain its shape
Glomerulus enclosed within a glomerular capsule; site of filtration
Consists of a pyramid, a portion of the cortex at the pyramid base, and a portion of the adjacent renal column
Apex of a renal pyramid; continuous with the minor calyx
Large cavity that receives urine from major calyces; continuous with the ureter
Portion of the nephron through which filtrate flows and is converted to urine
Repeating, cone-shaped structural unit found in the medulla with its base facing the cortex and its apex facing the hilus
Blood vessel exiting the kidney carrying filtered, deoxygenated blood to the inferior vena cava
Branch from the renal artery; branches into interlobar arteries
Tube that connects the kidney to the urinary bladder
Blood vessel that returns blood to the heart

pageData.altText: Figure 8: Labeled diagram of a neuron and its components
Figure 9: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the medulla, pons, and cerebellum labeled.
Figure 10: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the midbrain labeled.
Figure 11: A longitudinal cross section of the human brain with the hypothalamus, thalamus, and pineal body labeled.
Figure 12: The human brain with the frontal, parietal, temporal and occipital lobes highlighted and labeled.

tableData.text: Branching white matter within the cerebellum
Part of the brain that connects with the spinal cord; consists of the midbrain, pons, and medulla
Portion of the brain located caudal to the cerebrum; important in learning and coordinating motor activities
The superficial gray matter of the cerebrum and cerebellum

Most prominent portion of the mammalian brain; communicates with the cerebellum, controls voluntary motor activities; responsible for higher mental processes such as thought, memory, and judgment; divided by the medial longitudinal fissure into left and right hemispheres; divided into four regions or lobes
White matter tract connecting the right and left cerebral hemispheres
Consists of the cerebrum, thalamus, pineal body, and hypothalamus
Part of the cerebrum; involved with cognitive processes, such as planning and inhibition of drives
Ridges on the surface of the cerebral cortex (singular, gyrus)
The right and left halves of the cerebrum, separated by the medial longitudinal fissure and linked by the corpus callosum
Consists of the cerebellum, pons, and medulla
Part of the forebrain located just inferior to the thalamus; functions in both the nervous and endocrine systems and controls homeostatic, reproductive, and circadian functions
Deep cleft on the surface of the brain that divides the cerebrum into left and right hemispheres

Caudal part of the brain stem, extending from pons to spinal cord; contains regulatory centers for breathing and heartbeat, and reflex centers for vomiting, swallowing, coughing, and sneezing; also called the medulla oblongata
Most rostral part of the brain stem; relay station for sensory and motor information; involved in control of eye movements
Posterior lobe of the cerebrum; receives sensory information from the eyes
Lie anterior to the optic chiasm and function in detection of airborne chemical stimuli (i.e., odors)
Junction at which some fibers from the left and right optic nerves decussate (crisscross); necessary for binocular vision
Link the retinas of the eyes to the optic chiasm
Axons that convey visual information from the optic chiasm to the thalamus
Part of the cerebrum that lies between frontal and occipital lobes; integrates sensory information and functions in spatial perception
Small endocrine gland (also called the pineal gland) located just inferior to the thalamus; secretes the hormone melatonin and is important in control of circadian rhythms and onset of puberty

Part of the brain stem lying between the midbrain and the medulla; relay station between the spinal cord, cerebrum, and cerebellum; contains regulatory centers for various activities, including breathing and sleeping
Thin membrane located in the longitudinal midline of the cerebrum that separates the left and right lateral ventricles
Part of the CNS that links the brain to the PNS to convey sensory and motor signals; contains important reflex centers for movement
Depressions or grooves in the surface of the cerebral cortex (singular, sulcus)
Small paired mounds on the dorsal surface of the midbrain; important in control of head and eye movements in response to stimuli (singular, colliculus)
Part of the cerebrum; functions in auditory perception and long-term memory
Part of the forebrain located just beneath the cerebrum; serves as a relay station for motor and non-olfactory sensory information en route to the cerebral cortex
Series of four interconnected cavities within the brain that contain cerebrospinal fluid

pageData.altText: Figure 13: A diagram of light traveling from an object to the retina of an eye.
pageData.content: Figure 13. How light enters the eye

pageData.altText: Figure 14: A longitudinal cross section of a human eye with the cornea, iris, pupil, lens, coronary body, suspensory ligament, retina, and optic nerve labeled.
Figure 15: A longitudinal cross section of a human eye with the anterior and posterior compartments labeled.
pageData.content: Figure 15. The anterior and posterior eye compartments

tableData.text: Clear, watery fluid that fills the anterior chamber of the eye
Pigmented layer between the retina and sclera that absorbs scattered light; part of the vascular tunic of the eye
Muscular structure located posterior to the iris; attached to the lens via suspensory ligaments; part of the vascular tunic
Transparent anterior portion of the fibrous tunic of the eye
Outermost layer of the eye, consisting of the anterior cornea and posterior sclera
Indentation in the anterior portion of the vitreous humor that helps hold the lens in place
Pigmented diaphragm that alters pupil diameter to control the amount of light entering the eye
Biconvex, transparent structure that focuses light onto the retina
Innermost layer of the eye, or retina
The region of the retina where the optic nerve arises; contains no photoreceptors, and thus is commonly known as the “blind spot”
Links the retina of the eye to the brain; also called cranial nerve II
Anterior boundary of the photoreceptor-containing portion of the retina; has a serrated appearance in many vertebrate species
Opening in the center of the iris that changes diameter to regulate the amount of light entering the eye
Nervous tunic of the eye; contains rod and cone photoreceptors, plus additional types of neurons that process and transmit visual input
Posterior part of the fibrous coat of the eye; covers most of the outer surface of the eye; commonly known as the “white of the eye”

Fibers that join the ciliary body to the lens, thereby holding the lens in place and allowing contraction and relaxation of the ciliary body to adjust the shape of the lens; also called the zonula ciliaris
Reflective region of the choroid present in some vertebrates; enhances vision in low-light conditions
The middle layer of the eye, consisting of the choroid, iris, and ciliary body
Clear, gelatinous substance that fills the posterior compartment of the eye; also called the vitreous body

pageData.altText: A map describing the procedural workflow for this investigation. To prepare, set up the work area and dissection tools. In Activity 1, locate and identify external structures of a heart. Then, divide it along the frontal plane, and locate and identify its internal structures. In Activity 2, locate and identify external structures of a kidney. Next, divide it in half longitudinally, and locate and identify its internal structures. Then, open and examine the ureter. In Activity 3, locate and identify external structures of a brain. Next, divide it in half longitudinally, and locate and identify its internal structures. Then, create a cross section of the frontal lobe, and identify the cerebral gray and white matter. In Activity 4, remove excess superficial fatty tissue from an eye, and locate and identify the eye’s external structures. Next, divide it into anterior and posterior halves. Then, locate and identify the structures of the anterior and posterior halves.

data.title: Afferent arterioles
data.content: Small arteries from which blood enters a capillary network

data.title: Anterior
data.content: Toward the front of the body; synonymous with ventral

data.title: Antidiuretic hormone (ADH)
data.content: A peptide that promotes the formation of concentrated urine by the kidneys

data.title: Aorta
data.content: The largest artery which receives the systemic output of the heart

data.title: Aqueous humor
data.content: The watery fluid that fills the anterior compartment of the mammalian eye; it contributes to maintaining the spherical shape of the eye

data.title: Arachnoid
data.content: The meninges of the brain located between the dura mater and pia mater

data.title: Arbor vitae
data.content: The deep layer of the hindbrain that consists of branching white matter

data.title: Arcuate arteries
data.content: Blood vessels that run between the cortex and medulla of the kidneys

data.title: Arcuate veins
data.content: Blood vessels that drain blood from the interlobular veins of the kidneys

data.title: Atria
data.content: The two upper chambers of the heart that receive blood as it enters the heart; also called "receiving chambers"

data.title: Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP)
data.content: A hormone secreted from the right atrium when cardiac muscle cells are stretched

data.title: Atrioventricular valve
data.content: A valve between an atrium and ventricle of the heart

data.title: Axon
data.content: The part of a neuron that conveys impulses away from the cell body

data.title: Basal nuclei
data.content: Collections of gray matter embedded in the white matter of the brain

data.title: Bicuspid valve
data.content: the valve that prevents regurgitation as blood flows from the left atrium to the left ventricle; also called the mitral valve

data.title: Blind spot
data.content: The small place at the back of the retina where there are no rods or cones and the optic nerve enters the eyeball

data.title: Cardiac cycle
data.content: The synchronized series of contractions and relaxations of the heart chambers

data.title: Cardiac muscle
data.content: The type of muscle tissue that makes up the wall of the heart; it is characterized by striations that are often not as pronounced as those of skeletal muscle, and fibers that are arranged parallel to one another or often split into branches

data.title: Cardiac veins
data.content: Blood vessels that return oxygen-poor blood from the walls of the heart to the pulmonary circulation

data.title: Cardiovascular center
data.content: The part of the human brain that regulates heart rate

data.title: Cell body
data.content: The part of a cell that houses the nucleus and most of the organelles; also called the soma

data.title: Central nervous system (CNS)
data.content: The part of the nervous system composed of the brain and spinal cord

data.title: Cerebellar cortex
data.content: The superficial layer of the hindbrain that consists of gray matter

data.title: Cerebellum
data.content: A part of the hindbrain; cauliflower-like in appearance, it is of great importance in motor (movement) control

data.title: Cerebral cortex
data.content: The superficial layer of the forebrain that consists of gray matter and is highly wrinkled to increase its surface area

data.title: Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)
data.content: The clear, colorless fluid that fills the central nervous system (CNS)

data.title: Cerebrum
data.content: The most prominent portion of the mammalian brain; it communicates with the cerebellum, controls voluntary motor activities, and facilitates higher mental processes

data.title: Chordae tendinae
data.content: Fibrous cords that connect atrioventricular valves with papillary muscles; also referred to as the "heart strings"

data.title: Choroid plexus
data.content: A specialized epithelium that produces the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF)

data.title: Ciliary body
data.content: A muscular structure that is attached to the lens and is located immediately posterior to the iris; it alters the shape of the lens to enable near or distant focus

data.title: Collecting duct
data.content: A kidney duct that collects urine from the nephrons

data.title: Cornea
data.content: The transparent part of the coat of the eyeball that covers the iris and pupil

data.title: Coronary artery
data.content: The artery that branches from the aorta as it leaves the heart

data.title: Corpus callosum
data.content: The part of the brain that connects the left and right cerebral hemispheres

data.title: Deep
data.content: A significant distance below the surface

data.title: Dendrites
data.content: The part of a neuron that convey impulses toward the cell body

data.title: Distal convoluted tubule
data.content: The part of the nephron that lies between the loop of Henle and the nonsecretory part of the nephron; here, solute concentrations are adjusted

data.title: Dorsal
data.content: Toward the back or spine; synonymous with posterior

data.title: Dura mater
data.content: The outermost of the meninges; also known as just the "dura"

data.title: Efferent arteriole
data.content: The blood vessel that carries blood away from the glomerulus of a nephron

data.title: Endocardium
data.content: The thin membrane lining the cavities of the heart

data.title: Epicardium
data.content: The outer connective tissue layer that encloses the heart

data.title: Fibrous tunic
data.content: The outermost of three concentric layers of the eye; it consists of the cornea at its anterior half and the sclera at its posterior half

data.title: Filtrate
data.content: The fluid containing water and solutes from blood filtered by the kidneys

data.title: Forebrain
data.content: One of three major regions of the brain; it consists of the hypothalamus, thalamus, pineal body, and cerebrum

data.title: Fourth ventricle
data.content: One of four ventricles of the brain; it is located between the cerebellum and the brain stem

data.title: Frontal lobe
data.content: One of four lobes of the brain; it is responsible for cognitive processes such as planning, reasoning, judgement, and the control of emotional and sexual drives

data.title: Frontal plane
data.content: Divides the body into dorsal and ventral portions

data.title: Glia
data.content: A type of nervous system cell that provides support for the neurons; also called glial cells or neuroglia

data.title: Glomerular capsule
data.content: The filtration structure that is part of the glomerulus; also called "Bowman’s capsule"

data.title: Glomerulus
data.content: One of two structures that make up a nephron; it is a capillary network around the nephron where waste products are filtered from the blood

data.title: Gray matter
data.content: The darker tissue of the brain and spinal cord consisting mainly of neuronal cell bodies, dendrites, short unmyelinated axons, glia, and tiny blood vessels

data.title: Gyri
data.content: The wrinkles in the cerebral cortex; singular, gyrus

data.title: Hindbrain
data.content: One of three major regions of the brain; it includes two parts of the brain stem (which links the brain and spinal cord), the medulla, the pons, and the cerebellum

data.title: Homeostasis
data.content: A self-regulating process by which biological systems maintain stability while adjusting to environmental changes

data.title: Hyaloid fossa
data.content: An indentation in the anterior portion of the vitreous humor of the eye that helps hold the lens in place

data.title: Hypothalamus
data.content: A part of the brain that contains specialized hormone-secreting neurons and is thus considered part of the endocrine system as well as the nervous system

data.title: Inferior
data.content: Below, under

data.title: Interlobar arteries
data.content: The secondary branches of the renal arteries

data.title: Interlobar veins
data.content: The secondary branches of the renal veins

data.title: Iris
data.content: The colored part of the eye

data.title: Loop of the nephron
data.content: The portion of the nephron at which the descending limb makes a hairpin turn, reversing its orientation; also called the "loop of Henle"

data.title: Major calyx
data.content: The portion of the kidneys that collects urine from several minor calyces and conveys it into the renal pelvis

data.title: Medial longitudinal fissure
data.content: A deep groove that divides the brain into right and left hemispheres

data.title: Medulla
data.content: The portion of the brain that is continuous with the spinal cord and regulates involuntary activities such as breathing, heartbeat, vomiting, coughing, and sneezing

data.title: Meninges
data.content: A series of three connective tissue layers that protects the central nervous system (CNS)

data.title: Midbrain
data.content: The third part of the brain stem and one of three major regions of the brain; it serves to relay sensory and motor information between the spinal cord and the rest of the brain

data.title: Midsagittal plane
data.content: Divides the body into equal left and right halves

data.title: Minor calyx
data.content: The portion of the kidneys that collects urine from the papilla

data.title: Myelin
data.content: A fatty substance that surrounds the axon of a neuron and facilitates signal conduction away from the cell body

data.title: Myocardium
data.content: The muscular layer of the heart wall

data.title: Nephron
data.content: The functional unit of the kidney

data.title: Nerve
data.content: A bundle of myelinated axons that transmits impulses of sensation to the brain or spinal cord, and impulses from these to the muscles and organs

data.title: Nerve impulse
data.content: An electrochemical signal

data.title: Nervous tunic
data.content: The innermost of three concentric layers of the eye; it consists of the retina and photoreceptor cells

data.title: Neuron
data.content: A type of nervous system cell that is responsible for receiving sensory input from the external world and for sending motor commands to the muscles

data.title: Occipital lobe
data.content: One of the four lobes of the brain; it receives and processes visual information

data.title: Olfactory bulb
data.content: A rounded mass of tissue under the frontal lobe of the brain that contains several types of nerve cells that are involved in the sense of smell

data.title: Optic chiasm
data.content: The X-shaped structure near the base of the brain near the hypothalamus where the pair of optic nerves come together and decussate (crisscross) before continuing to the thalamus via the optic tract

data.title: Optic disc
data.content: A small area at the rear of the eyeball where rods and cones contact other nerve cells in the retina

data.title: Optic nerve
data.content: The convergence of nerve fibers in the optic disc that conveys signals to the brain

data.title: Optic tract
data.content: The extension of the optic nerve located in the brain

data.title: Ora serrata
data.content: The anterior boundary of the photoreceptor-containing portion of the retina

data.title: Osmoregulation
data.content: The control of solutes, mostly ions, in blood and other body fluids

data.title: Papillary muscles
data.content: Muscles found in the walls of the ventricles that anchors the chordae tendinae

data.title: Parietal lobe
data.content: One of four lobes of the brain; it integrates sensory information (for example, from receptors in the skin) and functions in spatial perception, i.e., the ability to assess the shape, size, orientation, and motion of objects

data.title: Peripheral nervous system (PNS)
data.content: The part of the nervous system composed of a network of nerves that extend throughout the body

data.title: Peritubular capillaries
data.content: The capillaries surrounding the renal tubule

data.title: Pia mater
data.content: The innermost of the meninges

data.title: Pineal body
data.content: A tiny endocrine gland located just inferior to the posterior portion of the thalamus of the brain

data.title: Pons
data.content: An important relay center of the brain that helps regulate sleeping and breathing

data.title: Posterior
data.content: Toward the back of the body; synonymous with dorsal

data.title: Principle of complementarity of structure and function
data.content: The scientific prinicple that each anatomical structure reflects its function and vice versa

data.title: Proximal convoluted tubule
data.content: The first segment of the renal tubule

data.title: Pulmonary circulation
data.content: The circulation pathway that carries deoxygenated blood away from the heart through the capillaries in the lungs and then returns oxygenated blood to the heart

data.title: Pulmonary valve
data.content: A valve between the pulmonary artery and the right ventricle of the heart that prevents blood from flowing back into the right ventricle

data.title: Pupil
data.content: The round opening in the center of the iris of the eye

data.title: Renal artery
data.content: The main blood vessel that supplies blood to a kidney and its nearby adrenal gland and ureter

data.title: Renal capsule
data.content: A thin, transparent layer of connective tissue that covers the external surface of the kidney

data.title: Renal columns
data.content: The portion of the kidneys that separates the renal pyramids and renal papillae

data.title: Renal corpuscle
data.content: The portion of the kidneys composed of the glomerulus and its capsule

data.title: Renal cortex
data.content: The outer portion of the kidney

data.title: Renal lobes
data.content: The cone-shaped structures of the kidney that each contain a renal pyramid

data.title: Renal medulla
data.content: The inner portion of the kidney

data.title: Renal papilla
data.content: The apex of the renal pyramid where the collecting ducts converge

data.title: Renal pelvis
data.content: The area at the center of the kidney

data.title: Renal pyramid
data.content: The inner medulla region of the kidney

data.title: Renal tubule
data.content: One of two structures that make up a nephron; it is a tiny tube that returns nutrients, fluids, and other substances that have been filtered from the blood

data.title: Renal veins
data.content: Blood vessels that carry blood from the kidney

data.title: Retina
data.content: The photoreceptive system in the back of the eye

data.title: Right lateral ventricle
data.content: One of four ventricles of the brain located in the cerebrum and separated from the left lateral ventricle by the septum pellucidum

data.title: Left lateral ventricle
data.content: One of four ventricles of the brain located in the cerebrum and separated from the right lateral ventricle by the septum pellucidum

data.title: Sagittal plane
data.content: Divides the body into longitudinal left and right portions

data.title: Sclera
data.content: The posterior part of the fibrous tunic that protects the eye and helps maintain the shape of the eyeball

data.title: Segmental arteries
data.content: Branches of the renal artery

data.title: Semilunar valves
data.content: The valves between the aorta and left ventricle, and between the pulmonary trunk and right ventricle; often called the aortic valve and pulmonary valve, respectively

data.title: Septum pellucidum
data.content: The structure of the brain that separates the right and left lateral ventricles

data.title: Subarachnoid space
data.content: The space between the pia mater and the arachnoid of the central nervous system (CNS)

data.title: Superficial
data.content: Toward or along the surface

data.title: Superior
data.content: Above, over

data.title: Superior colliculi
data.content: The part of the midbrain that helps control the movement of the eyes, head, and neck in response to a stimulus (e.g., a sudden loud noise or flash of light)

data.title: Suspensory ligaments
data.content: Connective tissue t hat attaches the ciliary body to the lens in the eye

data.title: Systemic circulation
data.content: The circulation pathway that carries oxygenated blood to and returning deoxygenated blood from the tissues of the body

data.title: Tapetum lucidum
data.content: A reflective region found in the choroid of many animals (e.g., cows, cats, and dogs; not humans) that enhances night vision

data.title: Temporal lobe
data.content: One of four lobes of the brain; it functions in auditory perception (including language) and long-term memory

data.title: Thalamus
data.content: A very important relay center in the brain

data.title: Third ventricle
data.content: One of four ventricles of the brain located between the two halves of the thalamus

data.title: Tracts
data.content: Bundles of myelinated axons in the central nervous system (CNS)

data.title: Transverse plane
data.content: Perpendicular to the long axis; produces cross-sections

data.title: Tricuspid valve
data.content: The valve that prevents regurgitation as blood flows from the right atrium to the right ventricle; it consists of three thin flaps

data.title: Ureter
data.content: The duct that carries urine from a kidney to the bladder

data.title: Urethra
data.content: A duct by which urine leaves the body; in males, sperm also leaves the body by the urethra

data.title: Urinary bladder
data.content: A temporary storage organ for urine

data.title: Urine
data.content: The fluid produced by the kidneys that contains waste as well as other substances, such as water

data.title: Vascular tunic
data.content: The middle of three concentric layers of the eye; it contains vascular tissue

data.title: Ventral
data.content: Toward the belly or abdomen; synonymous with anterior

data.title: Ventricles
data.content: The two lower chambers of the heart that forcefully eject blood from the heart; also called "pumping chambers"

data.title: Vitreous humor
data.content: A gelatinous fluid that fills the posterior compartment of the eye; it contributes to maintaining the spherical shape of the eye

data.title: White matter
data.content: The lighter tissue of the brain and spinal cord that consists of myelinated axons
